unnormalised: AIIMS Delhi recently reported a surge in cases of acute gastroenteritis, particularly among children under 5 yrs. Dr. Rajesh Kumar, HoD of Gastroenterology, addressed the press earlier today, highlighting the importance of hygiene during the ongoing monsoon season. He emphasized that proper handwashing, especially after using the restroom and before meals, is crucial to prevent the spread of infection.
normalised: A-I-I-M-S Delhi recently reported a surge in cases of acute gastroenteritis, particularly among children under five years. Doctor Rajesh Kumar, H-O-D of Gastroenterology, addressed the press earlier today, highlighting the importance of hygiene during the ongoing monsoon season. He emphasized that proper handwashing, especially after using the restroom and before meals, is crucial to prevent the spread of infection.

unnormalised: The primary culprit, according to Dr. Kumar, seems to be contaminated water. He advised boiling drinking water for at least 1 minute to kill any harmful bacteria or viruses. He also cautioned against consuming street food from vendors who may not adhere to strict hygiene standards. Many vendors selling pani puri near India Gate have seen a sharp drop in sales.
normalised: The primary culprit, according to Doctor Kumar, seems to be contaminated water. He advised boiling drinking water for at least one minute to kill any harmful bacteria or viruses. unnormalised: Symptoms of gastroenteritis include vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal cramps, and fever. Dr. Kumar urged parents to seek immediate medical attention if their child exhibits these symptoms, particularly if the child is unable to keep down fluids or shows signs of dehydration. A quick visit to your local GP can nip it in the bud.

A quick visit to your local G-P can nip it in the bud.

unnormalised: The hospital has seen approx. 150 cases in the last week alone, a significant increase compared to the monthly average of 60-70 cases. The majority of patients are being treated with oral rehydration solutions (ORS) to combat dehydration. In severe cases, intravenous fluids may be necessary.
normalised: The hospital has seen approximately one hundred and fifty cases in the last week alone, a significant increase compared to the monthly average of sixty to seventy cases. The majority of patients are being treated with oral rehydration solutions (O-R-S) to combat dehydration. In severe cases, intravenous fluids may be necessary.

unnormalised: "Prevention is always better than cure," Dr. Kumar reiterated. "Simple measures like washing hands frequently and ensuring the safety of drinking water can go a long way in preventing gastroenteritis." He also recommended avoiding close contact with individuals who are already infected. Maybe skip that visit to your cousin in Mumbai for now.

unnormalised: The AIIMS administration has launched a public awareness campaign to educate the public about gastroenteritis and its prevention. Information pamphlets are being distributed in Hindi and English at various locations throughout Delhi, including railway stations, bus terminals, and markets. Look out for them!

unnormalised: Dr. Kumar also mentioned that research is underway to develop more effective vaccines against common gastroenteritis-causing viruses. He hopes that a vaccine will be available within the next few yrs, providing long-term protection against this debilitating illness. Fingers crossed! This could really help children across India and elsewhere.
